headline: Great Place To Work
pros:
- Competitive pay for the industry with great perks and flexibility. I had decent dental insurance while being part time. 

- Management is promotion based. Somebody above you has been where you are at one point. A store manager has to start as a level 1 associate like everybody else in store. 

-Six figure salary plus bonus for store managers 

-Merit-based promotions 

-Free burgers
cons:
- Strict about weird things like hair color and tattoos
(I hope this has changed)

- You will end up being held late past your scheduled time off

- The environment is very micromanaged

headline: Hit or miss - can be toxic or amazing
pros:
company values - servant leadership (even if it's only modeled by a small percentage of leadership in the stores)

so many opportunities for growth and expansion

community and connection - having a family at work 

good intentions

when you find a manager who's in their heart and truly embodies what the company is about, WOO! everything changes - that manager will love you, lift you, and walk with you as you soar to new heights every day. That manager will challenge you and help you grow - that manager will make it all worth being there for because you will feel wanted, seen, valued, and loved :)

free burger and fries!! omg the fries are soooo goood!


you will learn so much about business, yourself, relationships, and your path!
cons:
not paid nearly enough for the emotional, physical, spiritual, and mental labor. we lose amazing associates because the pay is too low for the reality of the work. usually there are 1-5 toxic people in a store, often in leadership roles, and the ways they disempower others goes unchecked often. bullying and is a real problem in the stores - it's often very subtle and goes unnoticed. taking out emotions on associates is also normalized by leadership. harmful ways of communicating and relating goes without consequence, creating uncomfortable environments, especially for empathic people 

this is not for all the stores. there are definitely leaders in the company who model the company's true values and these people are so compassionate, they protect the space, and they recognize and value others.

headline: great
pros: Best job ever ! Great job for high schoolers
cons: None what so ever at all

headline: A company that truly cares about their employees.
pros:
- tons of support resources, employee assistance program for anything you could need in terms of life events
- plenty of employee events like tournaments and picnics
- extremely flexible schedule, shift start times ranging from 5am to 8:30pm
- free burger up to a double double every shift you work
- many people are very passionate about this company, makes it fun to work with people who enjoy what they do :)
- opportunity for advancement. promotions go level 1-level 7, then 4th manager, 3rd manager, 2nd manager, and store manager. Above that is DM, RM, and operations. or you could work in the warehouse.
- corporate are literally sweethearts. some of the nicest ppl you’ll ever meet. people who truly have a passion for ino and it’s history.
cons:
- your shift is based on business. if you’re full time and are scheduled to be off at 8pm during a rush, you will likely stay until it slows down again whenever that may be.
- I think we pay the tax on our break burgers but it’s small
- the scheduling is rough, especially full time. I don’t know my schedule until a week and a half ahead of time. it makes it hard to plan things outside of work.

headline: Make the Most Out of It or You Will Burnout
pros:
- Training is one of the best things INO does
- Compared to other food-service jobs, you are taken care of much better here
- INO culture is among the best (depending on store location), but especially in the corporate offices
cons:
- Service-Industry jobs are always going to be understaffed
- Food Industry jobs will always focus on profits and different managers will care about it more than others
- Fast-paced, but everyone struggles together
- Like anywhere else, management can be either be good, bad, or anything in between. That includes your level 7's and 8's for the INO stores.
- Turn-Around shifts

headline: A changing and challenging environment.
pros:
-Pay is above average and you are able to earn more relatively fast.
-It is relatively easy to move up in the company. 
-The bonds you build with coworkers and the events the company holds are very cool!
-When properly staffed it can be fun to be working as a team, it won’t really feel like working sometimes.
-They work really well around people's schedules and are good with accommodations.
cons:
- You are sometimes set up for failure due to a lack of associates on a shift. This can lead to extremely stressful days of work.
- There are many customers who are coming to In N Out and most of them are nice and a pleasure to serve, but there are always a few (like in any job) that basically harass you.
-If understaffed it can feel like you are just being used and overworked by the managers. 
-It is expected to be texted on days off and possibly be called into work.

headline: Pretty good place to work
pros:
- Well-organized management reduces common issues with franchises 
- Consistent opportunities for promotion 
- Flexible schedule 
- Generally positive work environment (pre-Covid)
- Good pay for a fast-food job 
- Generally well-trained managers
cons:
- Exceptional workers are taken advantage of (always asked to come in on days off or stay late, given additional responsibilities without extra pay, made to work closing shifts every night, made to train new hires while also maintaining job performance with no warning or guidance...) 
- Staffing shortages make every shift more difficult 
- Undue burden placed on higher level associates 
- Difficult to adjust as a new hire
- Company culture is a little weird and forced -- customer almost always placed before employee comfort/safety

Company focus is strictly on cleanliness and customer satisfaction which makes the culture easy to fit into.
cons: Extremely short breaks and you are constantly expected to be moving, cleaning, or helping a customer in some way. There can be favorites among the higher levels and that causes a caddy atmosphere at times. Training is more along the lines of “jump right in” and “hurry up”!

headline: I learned a lot, but wouldn't do it again.
pros:
-Free burger, fries, and drinks every shift.
-They teach you great customer service skills.
-They teach you the importance of presentation with uniforms.
-Some of the co-workers are really cool people.
-The restaurant is clean and aesthetically pleasing.
-You get to make people smile.
-The family atmosphere is cool, and the kids that want hats and stickers are cute.
-Alot of solid regulars. 
-Many of the in n out associates and management try to build comradery.
-Chances for moving up.
cons:
-A few managers have aggressive and rude tactics for leadership.
-The workplace politics are annoying (favoritism,etc).
-racial discrimination issues within the workplace. It's the types of comments and behavior you can't report, they're slick with it. Me and a few other associates discussed it. Does not apply if you don't experience that sort of thing. If you know, you know. 
-Workplace professionalism is not as strong as advertised. 
-ungenuine niceness.
-Only one ten minute break during 6 hr shifts, they are very militant about those 10mins. You have to work full time to get a 30 min lunch break, and you only get that after working a year or so. No time to eat while working long shifts.
-You are very overworked. 
-Not a great job for most college students.
-They are always trying to get people to work outside their availability. 
-No break room. 
-The changing closet and chair/desk for eating is claustrophobic-ly small.
 
Overall the job gave me slave plantation vibes lmao (but post modern all-american style), and I'm not immune to hard work but I wouldn't recommend it to anyone I know.

headline: Great place to work and grow
pros: The company structure is designed to help individuals grow and meet their potential. The top tier of corporate leadership follows the servant leadership method and encourages everyone down the chain of command to do the same. Excellent full-time benefits. Competitive pay. Very flexible schedule.
cons:
Hey man, it’s customer service. It’s not always easy. Humans are at their worst right before they’ve eaten and even the small locations serve ridiculous numbers of hungry people. 
The store atmosphere changes from store to store. If the manager is cool, it’s a fun place to work. If the manager isn’t, well, I’ve seen annual turnover peak at 118%. And while there is action to remove bad managers, it takes time and paperwork. The associates end up suffering.

headline: Working in HR  in Corporate
pros:
Coworkers are nice and helpful.

You get a free meal when you work Monday through Friday.

The people at the stores are nice. 

Other departments are helpful. 

Everyone values customer service.
cons:
For working in a corporate office setting:

The different HR groups don’t work with each other and everyone has a lane. It’s hard for people to learn about HR as a whole. For example, recruiters don’t work with benefits or HR partners, and HR generalists don’t work with learning and development. 

Most of the team members are part of a call center system where you have to drop your work to help the person on the phone. Even if you are salary, if you are not a leader you have to do this. 

They only give corporate employees 4 holidays per year and two weeks of vacation if you are there from 1-5years. Other companies start you at 3 weeks and give you at least 8 holidays. 

If you prefer flexible scheduling or working from home this isn’t the job for you. Leadership made it clear that they don’t allow office employees to work from home unless it’s required by some sort of mandate. Office employees were told that they are not a culture fit if they want to work from home or if they want a hybrid schedule.

The pay is not ‘competitive’. Other companies pay anywhere from 10k to 30k more for the same role with similar experience. 

The workload is too much. If you are hourly you are not allowed to work much overtime so you feel like you can’t catch up. If you are salary, then you will probably work an extra 1-2 hours each day and 2-5 hours on your off days to catch up. 

If you are salary they still expect you to be at the office between 5pm and 6pm depending on your position and there is no flexibility to leave early unless you get it approved by your boss. For example if you are salary you will not be allowed to leave at 4pm more than twice a week to pick up your kids from school/activities.

headline: Fantastic Company, but Choice of management....
pros: Flexible hours, community, benefits, and a company that is great to promote within.

My particular location had choice management, It felt like a hostile work environment and HR doesn't really have the associates backs. I will never work in a store flipping burgers again, However I would work in a corporate environment.

Also the company can be way more progressive. We live in 2021. Get over the 1950's mindset.

headline: Great company to work for, but certain stores vary in experience

cons:
management varies, rarely consistent with work ethic and attitudes
takes some time to level up especially if your store is not adamant on training
if part time, can’t get more than 30 hours a week

headline: First Job
pros: You get a lot of experience working in a fast paced environment. Level 3 and 4 managers get transferred to different stores quite often, so you get to experience a lot of management styles. The majority of associates are very young so it's a great environment to have fun whilst learning to multitask.
cons: Management can show a bit of favoritism and help level up their favorite employess. A lot of repetitive movements can take a toll on your body.

headline: Great management, but very physically demanding.
pros: This job is has extremely flexible hours, and very empathetic managers. You could choose to work one day a month, or 7 days a week, and you earn amazing money. It's a great place to walk into, and the positive vibes are always there. Interacting with all types of people each day was very uplifting, most of the time, and most of the associates were enthusiastic about being there. Also, you get gifts alot, and tons of benefits on the company store and with shoes (Doc Martins too).
cons: About every other customer thinks that you don't know anything, but the managers are great at working things out. It's extremely physically demanding even if you work out frequently with the constant lifting, scooping, and leaning. I ended up having to quit because I was having back spasms each night due to the stress that my back and legs were being put in.

headline: Good first job
pros: Great pay for first job definitely nice having free meals everyday you work and free soda.
cons: Stressful. Scheduling is a suggestion sometimes they’ll schedule you 5 hours and you’ll end up staying 8. Customers are ridiculous when ordering even tho the menu is simple and small. If the customer messes up there own order by saying it wrong your still at fault and will get talked to about by your manager.

headline: Good job to have... if you don't have any bills to pay or you don't care about getting promoted
pros:
- Flexible scheduling
- Free meals for employees
- Higher starting pay than most fast-food places
- Good benefits. Part timers get free dental and vision, full timers get full benefits.
- Most of the people you work with will become family to you outside of work. It's beautiful.
cons:
- Management plays favorites. If they like you, they'll train you. Doesn't matter how hard you work or how productive you are in the kitchen/in the drive-thru. 
- Management will lie to your face about giving you more training and more hours, then turn around and do the exact opposite. That's the reason why I quit. Empty promises and lies.
- If you have a visible tattoo or piercing, they won't hire you. Period.

headline: Good starter job

headline: Great place to work at... but
pros: Working at In-N-Out is awesome because you constantly receive raises whenever you level up in the company.. I began making $13.25 an hour, and in the course of 3 years, I left making $16.75... So the compensate you very well. And you get paid for holidays and a free burger whenever you work.
cons: I think the cons outweigh the pros... They're very strict about makeup, YOUR UNIFORM STAYING CLEAN (which can be very hard since you're working with food), alot of the times they run of uniform shirts, whivh typically I'm a small in women, but you'd catch me wearing a men's XXL... and you only take 10 min breaks which are TIMED by a massive tv in the kitchen so the can keep tabs on you, which sucks because you work 6 hrs at most and that's the only break you'd get... and there you are rushing to eat. Oh and its very stressful being forced to smile when the managers would yell out "SMILE CHECK"! Mentally unhealthy... and they live by "The customer is ALWAYS right" saying, so just know they'll never side with you no matter how ridiculous the situation can be. That's hurtful when a manager takes a complete stranger's side over yours, their own employee who they know.

headline: Best part time job
pros: You make way above minimum wage. The environment is very friendly. The company is also fun to work with when it comes to store parties and company events.
cons: It’s a fast paced environment. It can get stressful and is always constantly busy. Expect to be tired especially at a higher level.

headline: In N Out Associate
pros: In N Out has a great company culture. Most people are positive and work very hard. The corporate team and Snyder family really do care about their employees and make them a priority. Pay raises, paid time off, improved benefits are always happening. Great place to work at, especially in comparison to most fast food and service industry jobs. Most managers are also very good at working with your schedule.
cons: Very busy, very stressful. You will regularly find yourself physically exhausted at the end of the shift. There is almost never a dull moment. Customers expect a lot of you yet will often treat you very poorly.

headline: didn’t love it not for everyone

headline: Honesty, a great company.
pros: It was my first job and I stayed for 5 years. I know it varies around stores depending on store managers, but I always loved mine. They understand that life happens and some things in life are more important than your job, and honestly they don’t hire people who aren’t compassionate or kind. They offer a lot of opportunities for advancement in management and corporate.
cons: It’s high pace work, like a beehive. You will never have a second to breathe but that’s okay.

headline: In-N-Out is fantastic

headline: Great Place to work
pros: Food and family-like work environment, everyone is there to help you succeed there aren't many companies like it in this world.
cons: No cons, this place is a great place to start a career or just have part-time employment while figuring out what you want to do with your life.

headline: Great pay & good benefits
pros: 401k being part-time? Yes Please! Good benefits for part-time and full-time. Associates are friendly and training is the best. Training is detailed and coworkers are helpful.
cons: Repetitive motions while in a work position. Some can't handle the fast-paced environment. Since covid, we get excluded from work for 10 days if we call out over the tiniest symptoms.

headline: Great
pros: Free meal with each shift, flexible schedule, great for students or anyone looking to work part-time.

headline: it was an experience

headline: Great

headline: A job with great benefits and room to grow
pros:
-Above minimum wage pay ($16+)
-Lots of opportunities to get raises as you level up (which could take time depending on the store)
-Full time/Part time benefits
-Free burger and fries each shift
-Flexible (good for college students)- my manager was very accommodating with my school schedule and requested time off
-Sick hours and vacation hours are separate
-Managers aren’t hired externally. Everyone is “leveled up” towards being a cook and some get promoted to level 7 which is pre-management or like a supervisor type of role. There is a lot of room to grow and managers make a lot of money
-Made life long friends through the company
cons:
(Applies only to some stores)
-Stores in certain areas/cities are definitely busier than others. You should familiarize yourself with the one you’re applying to is in because it can get pretty stressful as a new hire, so prepare yourself!
-Work environment can be toxic
-Some managers play favorites which can either make your shift easy or more difficult than it needs to be
-Hierarchy between levels
-Repetitive movements. Make sure to do your pre-shift stretches and micro stretches throughout the shift because it really takes a toll over the years especially in the wrists

headline: Overall

headline: Fast, Fast, Fast
pros:
- good pay, it can range from 16 -20 an hour (if you are in CA) with a lot of raises 
- can be fun, can be stressful learning the new things at first but feels like a game after a while. 
- never slow. you will always have something to do
- free food. thats the best part. 
- flexible
cons:
- your schedule is just a suggestion. They will constantly never let you out on time... and I mean that by 30 minutes to 3 hours. your 3 hour shift will turn into 6 and no one asks you if you can stay longer either, they just make you. (they actually have you sign a contract that says they can keep you as long as they need you.) They also will end up calling you and asking you to come in for work on almost all of your days off. 
- coworkers can be snobby. we work by levels, meaning new people start at level1 and you progress to higher levels. the people who are higher levels than you are for some reason very snobby and rude.

headline: A great company to work for

cons: Depending on which tore you work at the managers might have a little power trip and try to walk all over the associates. Never be afraid to stand up for yourself. It does get super busy so beware of the fast paced environment you will have to put up with 90% of the time.

headline: In-N-Out is by far one of the greatest companies I have ever worked for.
pros: In my eyes In-N-Out is more than just a fast food restaurant, they are known all over the world, and everyone always wants to try it. They teach you to work hard everyday and strive to grow within the company. There is never a dull moment, and there is always something new to learn. There are definitely busy days where training can get hard, but the managers always make it priority to out the ones working on their next level in that position to push them to reach their goals. Everyone is always extremely friendly, allowing you to create a family out of your coworkers. You wont be disappointed working here.
cons: Its very fast paste, and it allows you to have a lot of multitasking. There is never down time with this company, you are always working hard and making time go by. Nothing bad about this company in my eyes, you just have to be a hard worker.

headline: In-N-Out Burger pros and cons
pros: Great leadership! I would often catch my managers telling average associates, like I myself was, “Good job!”, In a very sincere tone when they did something well. The professionalism of the managers and the cleanliness of the store was surprisingly a lot better than I imagined it would be. To put it into perspective, I have no problem eating there after having worked at In-n-out burger. I think it is the perfect job for a teenager who hasn’t worked for a company before. Great company.
cons:
They don’t offer full-time up front.

If you are planning on having Sunday’s off like chic-fil-a, don’t get your hopes up. The location that I worked at had a lot of people who attended church, so workers on Sunday were in high-demand.

I had a couple of co-workers who were bad apples, but I genuinely have nothing bad to say about the managment.

pros: Honestly, there are a lot. But to start, base pay is almost $3 above minimum wage. Also, room for growth which is based on a level system (1-6). Each time you level up, you get a raise. They offer a lot of additional services to help fellow associates going through trouble in life, and/or an immediate family member. Super fun company to work for although can be quite a challenge at times.
cons: You get paid above minimum wage for a reason. Don't expect this to be an easy job. Can get quite exhausting due to physically demanding labor, standing your whole shift, and are only allowed a 10 minute break unless you work 6 hours+.

headline: Way Overworked
pros: Decent pay, busy days and you get to work with some amazing people. Benefits are decent if you opt for them.
cons:
Stressful, underpaid, under-appreciated, poor management practices like moving managers around after 2 months, pushing certain numbers of cars through the drive lane to meet the bonuses of the managers... 
They also like doing this thing where the second you actually speak to your co-worker(could be about anything, a simple “how are you bud?”, they quickly find something else for you to do and separate you so that you don’t take away from thei margins. They will squeeze every last SECOND out of you and God-help you if you are not sweating and looking like your about to have an anxiety attack.
Lastly, their training is extremely inconsistent and they only push to TRAIN YOU ONCE YOU HAVE WORKED A CERTAIN THRESHOLD OF HOURS. They literally always wait until they HAVE to promote you. Folks, it has nothing to do with IF YOU CAN DO THE JOB, they make you anyway.

headline: Overall Good
pros: Decent pay. A lot of benefits offered. Good at building morale. Occasionally give In-N-Out branded gifts as rewards for good work. Overall a really good experience. Emphasize teamwork, sense of urgency, how quickly you can learn, following directions. Part-time you get some say in your schedule, but you must be available to work at least one night and one weekend shift.
cons: It is very demanding you can get overworked very easily. If you are a good worker you will rise quickly, but they do rely on you and again, can be very easy to get overworked. Physically can take a toll on your body, especially the more responsibilities you get. The most common is back, shoulder, and wrist pain. Full-time you really don't get a say in your schedule, will very likely be overworked. There is a lot of strict rules on appearance. No tattoos, piercing

headline: Fantastic company, can get very stressful
pros: I've never seen a company that puts employees first like In-N-Out does. All of our managers are very well trained and fantastic, the employee culture is very positive, and CEO is honestly the most down to earth and badass person. I worked at In N Out during the school year and they were more than willing to work around my schedule. If you work more than 3.5 hours you get a 10 minute break. The company does not let you work more than 6 hours on a shift unless you're working a double (anything longer than 6 hours... typically reserved for high level associates. I've worked for 10 months and have not gotten one yet). If you work a double you get a 10 minute and a 30 minute break.
cons: I work at a notoriously crazy location with VERY strict managers so take this with a grain of salt. It can get VERY busy. I often run at work. Sometimes you'll be multitasking 3 too many things. Just be aware that they expect a lot out of you. Also, they do not hire full time employees. It is something you have to earn by working with the company for a long time.

headline: Rewarding job for those who like to work hard

headline: Manager at in n out
pros: Some pros are the opportunity for growth,great training at corporate,associates you work with,and company events.
cons:
They dont care about work life balance. You will work until 3 am and be expected back at 10 am . You will be expected put in 55 hours a  week. Yes you get vacation time but a "request off isnt a guarentee".If you want to give your life to in n out this is the job for you.
-2nd they do not recognize hard work and producing the best numbers ....i never got less than a platinum on my shift but they promote the wrong people. They listen to gossip and dont look into facts.

headline: Great Place to Learn, But Don't Get Stuck
pros: I had a fantastic time and was paid really well.  I learned the traits and skills that I never would have learned if I didn't work at INO.  I highly suggest that you work here because it is a great experience and looks really good on resumes.
cons: It is hard taxing work and you have to work at a high standard (this is also a pro because it teaches you good work ethic).  If you are looking to get into the burger business definitely try to climb the ladder here.  But, if you want to move on with your life and go to college and get a career?  You need to be careful because I know many people who get sucked into this company and are too scared to leave their jobs.

headline: Modern day slavery
pros: Pays a little more than minimum wage.
cons: No benefits for part time, which is the majority of workers there. No discount. You WILL  develop carpel tunnel and arthritis over time, as well as burns and scars all over your arms from cooking. They brainwash you into thinking that you have it good there, seems almost like a cult. No breaks on time, customers come first. Also keep you for up to 3 hours past your scheduled shift without asking. Management poorly trained and favoritism is a huge problem. Managers often sleep with associates

headline: Companies like this are hard to come by
pros:
The company shows loyalty toward their workers at all levels.
The pay is exceptional.
Lots of opportunity for upward mobility.
You are rewarded for good performance.
The company is willing to pay for good people, which makes it easier to run a good operation.
There is generally stability at the highest levels, which gives a sense of predictability and security.
cons: None, other than those that go with the nature of the business..in the stores, work/life balance can be a challenge.

headline: Hands Down the BEST
pros: This company is seriously amazing, They take care of you, promote within, and have high standards for their quality of food and service.  The best work environment! Oh also, the BEST benefits i've everhad.
cons: the hours are odd,  this is not a 9-5. may be hard if you have children in school

headline: Filing A Complaint=Retaliation
pros: At my store, associates and the All Star Crew are friendly and willing to help you out. They are very supportive.
cons:
I did have an issue with a manager so I  filed a complaint. They say you can be anonymous and there will be no retaliation, but after I filed it, I started to experience some retaliation by my hours getting cut. The manager I told on started having me do more mundane tasks that made it harder for me to move up to the next level. 

So management WILL show some backlash/retaliation towards you if you  file complaints.

Part timers need more or longer breaks. Working for 5-6 hours straight with only a 10 minute break and you have to rush to isn't very restful.

headline: A very good job
pros: the pay is good compared to most fast food jobs, and pretty much everyone hired is nice. it’s also fairly easy to make a career out of it if you want to strive for that
cons: sometimes customers do take advantage of the good customer service and can be difficult to deal with, and if it’s busy it can be really exhausting and stressful. they also tend to expect a lot of hours from employees, and you might get scheduled or called in even if you requested the day off.

headline: It was not a good time working there.
pros: There are some cool people to work with at in n out. There are cool In n out sponsored activities that you can take part with and become closer to your coworkers. You also get a free meal every time you work
cons: The hours are very poor for part time associates.  The mangers at my store picked favorites and i got the poor end of the stick. I'm also unhappy with the way my co workers treated me because I was a "lower level". Its been impossible for me to earn a raise because in order for me to get the raise I have to work a certain position and they haven't allowed me to work/learn that position because how busy it gets.

headline: The best part-time job you can have under 18
pros: Flexible with work hours, genuine managers, real growth. You have meaningful meetings and several opportunities to move up in the company, the managers are the best managers I've had in my life and I've learned many lessons from them. It's insane how this is a fast food job but has corporate level morale and room for growth.
cons: I had several meetings for not socializing with my coworkers properly. I socialized with customers perfectly but it was a problem to the managers that I was shy. I would walk in for my shift and felt the entire room just drop in energy because my coworkers dreaded my presence. It really messed with my self-confidence, and the managers mentioned they wish I could "change my personality". So being shy or having social anxiety might ruin your time at In-N-Out, and my coworkers never failed to make me feel incredibly left out.

headline: Awful awful awful managers
pros:
Luckily, everyone there is in the same boat with you so the people you work with actually do become like your family. The parties they throw are pretty enjoyable. Stores go head to head in basketball games, baseball games, ect. A free meal period with every shift. Pays more than minimum wage...
I must say though, you make good money. Just be prepared; you will either absolutely love this job, or absolutely hate it. 
but the list of cons are extensive
cons:
Dude. There’s so much wrong with this place. I worked at my In-N-Out &  had a friend working at another In-N-Out and we both had the same stories and issues. Management sucks all around. Don’t expect to get off in time. They have no problem keeping you for hours past your scheduled shift. Complete disregard for employees training. And to be completely honest, it’s just not an easy job
Be prepared to always smell, deal with awful managers, and just wait for the back pain. Dress code is absolutely terrible as well.

headline: Okay starter job
pros:
- flexible schedule 
- coworker
cons:
- Over worked : the reason why the pay is “ average “  is because they work you for every penny. Most of the times I was working a station by myself that should have 3 people. 12 / hr might seem good as a starter but when your basically doing 3 jobs at a time, it’s not worth it.
- Stress : managers tend to be little you if you can’t live up to their unrealistic expectations of doing 3+ tasks at the same time in a small time frame
- Worked around great coworkers but was barely allowed to socialize due to always having to be kept busy even if that meant recleaning the walls
- leveling up was annoying due to them just throwing you on to something new without half decent training and getting upset when you’re not able to do it properly
- As a teen I would recommend a job like Starbucks but if you had to then go with in n out. Once you turn 18, QUIT. There are so many more high paying jobs that don’t make you work to the bone and offer a much better pay.
- once you start working here for more that 6 months you’ll feel stuck, remind yourself there is way better opportunities once your 18.

This company's value's are top of the line. Employer's have since told me they hired me because of my experience working at In n Out. Working here will follow you, in a good way, for your future career path.

headline: Good
pros: Great pay, in AZ start off at 11 an hour. There are many levels for advancement as you start as a level 1 then work your way up to level 7 with raises after each level. Training is great, you watch videos on how to do your job first then work with someone until you feel comfortable on your own. Free burger every shift. It’s great for in high school or college. Can also be a great career if you want to go into management as it pays 45k-110k.
cons: You can’t work full time unless you’re at least a level 7 which on average takes maybe 3 years. Customers can be dumb, like really dumb. Also it’s a busy place and can be very stressful but you get used to it.

headline: Associate
pros: Good benefits, always something to do, fast environment, first job experience
cons:
It's very sad that I hated my experience here because I feel like I could've really enjoyed the job itself. The problem was that after you pass those long interviews (3 interviews with different managers) they just throw you in without proper and thorough training. It was my first job & I was super eager to learn and excited to be working at in n out as everyone else seemed to like it there. Some of the employees do not support you, I had been told to ask any of my coworkers for any help or questions if I needed it. I asked one co-worker a question and she said "oh you're the new one, you don't know anything" I tried my absolute best, even a customer said "wow they work you like a dog here huh?" 
Ridiculous.

headline: Working as an associate

headline: Very strict place, management feels more important than the other employees.
pros: High salary, good benefits, growth opportunities- the growth ladder is literally a ladder in that it is a 7 step process to climb up the ranks and once you are level 7 you conduct training, work your way to management, etc.
cons: Working at In-n-Out burger requires you to be held to there high but seemingly meaningless standard. Working at an Austin location means you have to take everything you do and do it better than you ever would so that way if supervisors from the California headquarters come they can continue approving the way we are representing the brand, and that is really all they care about. If you show up with sideburns even a tiny bit too long, you get sent home, if you don't get a haircut (even though you wear a hat and girls hair isn't even in a hairnet, you get sent home. Management is unwilling to let you feel like you are a part of a community and makes you feel more like you are in a corporate machine. Will work you too late even when your availability states you cannot work late, many nights I was there until 2am with class at 9am the next morning, when I told management not to schedule me, I was not surprised to see that I had the same closing shifts (closing being 2am) as I did last week.

headline: Fun place to work

cons: There is not consistent pay across all stores. For example a level 6 (cook) gets paid 15 an hour at most stores, however in the Mill Valley and Milpitas location level 1 (cashier) start at 16 an hour.  Another Con is you will lose a normal sleep schedule as a normal week will consist of a couple day shifts (mids) and a couple closing shifts. Most closing shifts are from 5:30-2:15 which can be a challenge while also going to school in the morning.

headline: Still a Rather Good First Job Company
pros:
- Very friendly management team, accommodating and qualified to manage.
- Higher than minimum wage starting salary.
- Free meal if working over four hours in a day.
- Many support services if assistance is needed with work/personal problems.
- Good team diversity--there are older workers and high school students but also various ethnic backgrounds and about a 50/50 male:female ratio.
cons:
- As with all workplaces, a few less than particularly agreeable coworkers
- Differences in instructions--something said by one manager might be blown off by another and something a new hire is taught to do by a more experienced coworker might not be okay with the managers.
- Tasks are physically more difficult for shorter employees--not impossible but if you're under 5'3" sometimes you may not be able to reach some of the shelf items even with a stepladder. 
- If working 3-6 hour bursts, many times there will only be one job for the entire time. Washing dishes for 4 hours straight isn't only a drag, it's a pain for the shoulder as well.

headline: Amazing company, great people, they treat their employees well and pay great.

cons: Physically demanding, you’re on your feet the entire day, as well as constant movement and repetition of motions when on certain positions.

headline: Fun and Flexible
pros:
Working for In N Out is extremely rewarding. The company has high expectations, which causes the vast majority of store associates to rise to the levels expected of them. 

Everyone starts at a level one, but you are always working on getting your promotion to the next level. There 7 levels before management, and they only promote from within. 

The pay is excellent for a part time job. Associates start at $12.50, and you get a small raise every time you get to a new level. After two years, at a level 4, I was making $14.25 an hour. 

Everyone there helps one another. This is no teamwork makes dream work environment. Each person is expected to perform their individual duties well, and you will be called out when you don’t rise to their expectations. However, everyone knows that the more effectively they collaborate and communicate, the better the store does at meeting customer needs. 

Never had an major issues with other employees. It was a fun, light hearted, and engaging work environment. 

Free burger every shift!

Flexible with hours and scheduling.
cons:
You will spend a LOT of time on your feet. For every 6 hrs, you get a 10 min break.
If you’re lucky to work an 8, you’ll get an hour break. 

If you are not full time or a higher level or favored by management, you’ll never work more than a 6 hour shift. 

Depending on the store, you have to fight and use your voice to train for the next level. Only a few stores will start that process for you. 

If your store becomes over staffed, you’ll hardly every work.

headline: Great company
pros:
Amazing training program

cons:
Its fast food so of course it can be hard work. You'll go home tired and dirty.

headline: Great Job!

They've all been willing to teach and the attitudes have been consistently positive even during  a rush.  The benefits are also great and the pay is good as well. It definitely is not a job to slack off on, though. Good hours are given, and management has their stuff together. You also get to meet very nice people and make new friends!
cons: I really have nothing to complain about, however, since it is the restaurant business and it is fast food so you will deal with not-so-great costumers and crazy rushes but continue to be positive!

headline: Politics
pros: Fast and Simple! Free meal with every shift, but I recommend protein all throughout the week then splurge one day or else you will end up fat like most of the long term associates.

headline: Great Culture
pros: The company fosters a very positive environment in each store. Everyone comes in with a positive attitude and ready to work hard. They pay very well and reward you properly for the work you put in. There is plenty of room to move up so long as you prove your worth. It is a great job to have whether you are looking to make extra money on the side or want to look for something long term, as the managers typically make good money.
cons: It is a very demanding job and requires you to consistently be on the go. There isn't much downtime and if there is, someone will most likely be sent home. It may be hard to move up if you do not show your dedication or simply cannot perform tasks efficiently. There also seems to be a high turnover, with many people being relocated, especially managers.

headline: Good but Not Worth It
pros:
The pay. And that’s about it. 
Company picnic. 
Met few lifelong friends.
cons:
Managers are constantly changing. 
At my store the District Manager was very out of touch with what the store actually needed to do to improve and overall that stressed out the store manager who took it out on his employees. 
They think managers can be trained, but some are just horrible people who harass employees and cause anxiety. 
Hours are long, and my store manager was a jerk about even the slightest change in hours. 
Hostile work environment, at my store there was no sense of community among employees. 
I know not all stores are like this, but at this job I had the most anxiety and I was unhappy for years. 
Also the makeup / grooming policy is ridiculous. No winged eyeliner? Seriously? Get with the times. They turned away workers and terminated workers based on tattoos.

headline: Solid Job Opportunity

-Pay is very competitive

-Established promotion structure means you know what you need to do to get your next raise (raises occur pretty quickly in the lower levels)
-Since they aren't hiring from literally the bottom of the barrel your coworkers are generally great people
cons:
-Has the same cons as any food service job: lunch/dinner rushes can be crazy, some customers are rude, etc.
-More uptight about following rules than other food service jobs, though the procedural discipline here could also be seen as a positive since it helps you understand how a good company works
-With the high pay come high expectations; even when business is slow you cannot slack off

cons: Some cons are the stress it brings. It is a really hard job. Constant attitude is something you get used to but it is never taken personal. We get paid so good for a reason..... it is hard work. Extremely fast paced you must learn how to keep up or you will get kicked off your position and won't get your raises.

headline: Best place to work. The company has high expectations of employees, but the hard work is rewarded!
pros:
- Great wages and the benefits are awesome! Doctors offices always compare my benefits to military or education employees, and with the PPO option it’s sometimes better.
- Supervisors really try to get to know their employees and families. It always blows me away, that my department head (who is 3 or 4 supervisory levels over my immediate supervisor) remembers personal things about not just me, but my family, and shows genuine interest in my happiness and well being at both work and at home.
- Company has high standards and doesn’t cut corners. Makes it easy to do your job correctly when you don’t have to stress about being forced to take shortcuts. He company takes pride in doing things the right way the first time.
- Great opportunities for advancement and growth. I’ve worked in the stores and for several different departments within corporate. If you work hard and show that you are ready for advancement, your supervisors invest in your growth. The company truest wants you to move up and succeed.
cons:
- Company expects employees to work very hard. (No shortcuts from them as an employer means no shortcuts for employees. (Not really a con, it’s only a fair expectation, but some people don’t get the concept.)
- On feet all day.
- Fast paced environment, have to make sure to keep up.

headline: Worked Into the Ground
pros: Free burgers (even though they’re cheap already), decent pay for the torture they make you go through
cons: Disgustingly disrespectful, rude, idiotic, mindless, downright horrible customers which the company takes the side of in EVERY situation. You are worked to the bone, given the worst shifts, given every excuse in the book to not get promoted unless if you’re full time, and you are constantly harassed about looking the happiest to people who make you want to blow your brains out every moment of your shift. The CEO pretends like she cares, but in all reality she’s just sitting on a fortune and doing nothing new with it. At this job, you will never be good enough. You will receive very lackluster compliments for a job well done that are completely not genuine, followed by 2 things you did wrong. The worst people move up, and make your life as a lower level misery because the higher levels take out their frustration on you. This job is hell. There is no other way to say it, other than this job is complete and utter hell. You never get off on time, EVER. It may be 10 minutes or 2 hours, but your manager and your company couldn’t care less if you have a first date after work, they are going to work you to the ground because the customer’s appendage is rammed so far up In N Out’s rectum that they will do anything to make their experience a little quicker. My advice to anybody who has any ambitions in life? Don’t work here. This job sucks. I believed the hype and loved the job at first, and then you realize how much you really are overworked, and how little pay you receive in comparison to the complete beat down you go through every shift. AND THIS JOB IS ALL MICROMANAGEMENT.  A cult.

headline: Fast paced work with people who want to help.

headline: More than just flipping burgers!
pros: I was honestly surprised by how much I enjoyed my time at In-N-Out. I met so many amazing people, both coworkers and customers. The benefits are also awesome - the pay is great, we get PTO even as part-time associates, dental and vision insurance if you want it, and plenty of fun company events such as the family picnic and the softball tournament. In short - In-N-Out is a great first job to have.

headline: In-N-Out teaches you how to work hard, and it pays well especially for high schoolers.
pros: Very fast pace and friendly environment. Pays well. Easy to get hours. Management team likes to listen to you and get to know you.

headline: The best experience I could've gotten
pros: Honestly working for In-N-Out as my first job gave me all the skills I needed to do well in any other work environment. It instilled such a strong work ethic, the ability to manage time, work well alongside others, and just made me a better employee. Benefits were great and so were the friendships I made throughout my entire time there. I wish I never had to leave but the world is my oyster and they've provided me with a stable building block to succeed.
cons: It gets extremely tiring and some times more than others will test your patience. But the ability to grow overcomes all that!

headline: Associate Level 6

headline: To sum up my review "Unfair, and Stressfull"
pros:
The great variety of people and connections you can build.. that's about it. 
The benefits? Many other companies offer similar. Costco, Stater Bros,  Chik fil a, etc.
The pay.. I rather trade in my dollar extra that I make for a steady schedule and just work minimum. It's impossible to work part time and take care of others things.
cons:
The handling of the business is a mess, nothing is clear, management gets swapped around constantly, theyll mess up your availability often, its like war going on in the store nothings organized well.

Also, Insomia, anxiety, physically exhausting, and incredibly stress-full. Expect these things to get worse as you progress.

headline: If you can work there, you can work anywhere
pros: The training, the perks, the cleanliness, the customer service training, the family picnics.  It’s legitimately the best job I ever had.
cons:
Very tiring.  You’re overworked but not under paid.   It can be late hours sometimes.
You can never have a bad attitude or bad grooming, you’ll get sent home... which I like...
You can get stuck there... like a lot of people who started working there as a summer job in 2004 are still there.

headline: The best company I ever worked for.  Hands down.
pros:
INO is one of the few companies that genuinely puts their money where their mouth is.  They genuinely show concern for their Associates, and are extraordinarily generous and reward performance accordingly.  The environment is fun, and the pay and working conditions are wonderful.  The work is hard and physically fast-paced, but that makes it enjoyable and each day is different.

If you work in Corporate, same goes.  Extremely transparent working climate, generous pay, fair work environment and you feel cared for.  Show loyalty and commitment, and you get it back.  Talented people working here, committed to the vision.  Lots of loyalty to the company.  Good opportunity to move up, particularly if you have a degree.  If not, the opportunities can come a little more slowly.  But they're generally still there.
cons:
Being a Store Manager can be extraordinarily demanding, requiring strong time management, priorities, and leadership.  It may feel almost impossible to stay on top of everything. So you have to be on your game.

In exchange for achieving the desired results, the company rewards you handsomely.  So it's not really a "con", more like if you want the benefits, work hard and smart for them.  If you do, you can make lots of money and will have a company who has your back.

Given that the job is demanding, the work/life balance can be difficult.  Having said that, it's on you to make that work.  If you're disorganized or inconsistent in your performance, you'll have to put in more time because of your weakness.  In that case it may feel like you can't win or they expect too much.  But if you are on your game, it's manageable and very lucrative.  It's a job that rewards you if you perform.  

Like any company, the bigger they get, the more corporate they get.  Unavoidable, so not really a "con".  Just a fact.

headline: Definitely not for everyone
pros: The atmosphere is pretty great.  The company really cares for you. I got a set of Christmas lights with burgers, fries, shakes, and the in n out logo for Christmas courtesy of In-N-Out Burger. They are really into company events like softball, basketball, and golf tournaments as well as company picnics. They really make you feel like they care about their employees in a general sense.
cons: They work you HARD. You will work 3 positions at once. Not just you, EVERYONE. Honestly, it's not a bad thing, but it's hard. Everyone here is a BEAST. People that work here learn to multitask to the extreme. Unfortunately, it is super stressful and NOT for everyone. Imagine talking to 2 people at once while handing out food and making drinks and still being expected to help others out.

headline: In-N-Out can be a great place to work but can also be a nightmare. It depends on your store location and your managers.
pros:
Great starting pay (compared to other fast food restaurants)

Pay raises as often as every couple of months (frequency of raises depends on how much effort you put in and how much training they give you)

Other benefits like store parties, outings and prizes (for reaching store burger sale goals, or safety awards)

"Ladder climbing" (you get a raise every time you "level up" and can get into management fairly quickly if you work hard)
cons:
Training (depending on your managers and your store's location, training can be very hard to get and almost never consistent, even if you work hard and put in the time and effort. It's easy to get stuck at levels 3-5 because training is hard to get)

Manager turn-over (managers get promoted fairly quickly and every time they move up, they change stores, so you can have a dozen different managers come and go throughout the year making it hard to bond in some cases)

Smelly! (If you don't enjoy smelling like onions and spread/ketchup/mustard, this is not the job for you (:  )

Stressful (there is pressure just like any other place in the food industry to be fast and efficient during the rush times. It helps to have a cool head)

headline: If you like being stressed out and managed by your parents, it's your perfect fit
pros:
Free meal every time you work
Good pay
Advance quickly
Lots of incentives to do your best
cons: They have a level system which works very odd because it forces you to work against your coworkers to gain higher level/rank. It's very stressful and demanding work because they expect you to be perfect-- if you're not management will rain down on you. The customers are probably the worst part of the job because they are some of the most entitled people as they expect completely perfect service every time and if something is not to their liking they will throw tantrums. I felt discriminated against because only men were allowed to do certain tasks and men were allowed to wear revealing clothing such as muscle shirts while girls were penalized for wearing spaghetti straps (I am referring to the almost monthly staff meetings where we were allowed to wear casual dress).

cons: Being a fast food restaurant, you can't determine the level of business so there will be shifts where you will not be off on your scheduled time. You also cannot have visible tattoos, nail polish, unnatural hair color, or body piercings.

headline: Good company
pros: I love this place it was fun to work they're good people great pay you can move up fairly quickly

headline: I Love This Job !

headline: Good starting pay but very busy

your base starting pay is $12. 
Meet lots of people
get experience with customer service
if you like job rotation, this is the job for you
cons: I would be scheduled for a certain amount of hours but they will always be cut short for some reason. They are very strict with dress code. My coworkers at this specific store were a bit fake in my opinion, so I didn't avoided some of them. Training needs work. I had to figure things out by myself, then I would ask but they would act too busy to answer my questions and get reprimanded for trying to figure things out by myself.

headline: Store Associate
pros: Social work environment , flexible schedule , Many things to learn. Can be fun.
cons: TRAINING . Absolutely no training.  You have to ask other employees questions while they're working. Promotions handed out too easily. Managers come and go to quickly. Overworked staff/frustration.

headline: Looks better than it is.
pros: Good pay for starting job. Good room for advancement. Tons of training for you to know how to do your job well. Takes a lot of wrongdoing to be fired.
cons: Lots of lazy people and since it takes so much to get fired, they never are. Upper management has way to many new policies constantly being made, but they havn't worked in the stores for so long, they don't know how impossible it is to follow them all. Its always busy, to the point of ridiculousness.

headline: A Good High School Part-Time Work Experience
pros: Competitive pay and good benefits. Excellent training and clear-cut expectations.
cons: Very high standards regarding appearance and behavior. Not always realistic.

headline: General Overview
pros: Great Pay, Fast-Paced Work Environment, Fast Shifts, Successful Company
cons: Always busy, closing shifts suck (get off around 2-2:30 am)

headline: Level 2 associate
pros:
Fun fast food environment 
Great for a first job
Pay was great 11 an hr
cons:
After awhile the multi-tasking becomes overwhelming as you level up. 
Hours getting cut

headline: Level 4 Associate
pros: Positive atmosphere, Nice associates, chill but get-the-job done managers
cons: None off the top of my head

headline: Fully Certified Level 7 - All Star Trainer
pros: flexible hours, good pay and benefits, coworkers can become like family, opportunity for advancement
cons:
If you don't mind your life being ruled by the arrow, it's great. If you want to be a higher level and do something as simple as go to the doctor, you need to request that off at least a month in advance and pray you get the time off, otherwise some 16 year old kid can just call out and you are screwed. There is overtime - without any warning. You'll think you have only 10 minutes left on your shift, but then the shift manager TELLS you that you'll be staying longer and no, they don't know how much longer.

Also, the customer is right...to an extent. Customers are allowed to do and say whatever they want to you and if you even defend yourself, you WILL BE FIRED. I have seen a customer SPIT on an associate and the associate just had to stand there and take it and APOLOGIZE TO THE CUSTOMER.

headline: Associate
pros: Better than average pay, culture, environment
cons: Constantly busy and late shifts

headline: A hard job that pays off.
pros: A family atmosphere. Every day is rewarding. New challenges to face every day.
cons: It's hard work. You can get drained and jaded by customers.

headline: Level 6 Associate
pros: In N Out is a phenomenal company, especially if you are a working college student. They pay well, great management, peer training, and great benefits. This job is all about team work and encouraging each other.
cons: You're basically on a manufacturing line, except it's with food. It can be strenuous on your body.

headline: q
pros: Great people, great managers, great experience
cons: It's easy to get comfortable there

headline: Great Pay, Terrible Management, Outdated Systems
pros:
-Pay starts at $10.50, get a raise with each level increase
-Chance to enter managment without any external schooling
-Fast paced, rarely bored
-Free food every work day
-Company events are fun
-Gift every Christmas
cons:
-Despite leveling up being fairly straight forward as far as skills that need to be learned, who they decide to train is largely based on favoritism
-Company is basically a cult, management thinks that everything they are doing is the best possible way to do it so critiques largely go to the wayside
-Arizona and cooking means you'll be sweating
-If you don't absolutely love In-N-Out you might clash with the culture
-You'll get in the habit of saying "Right on" for everything

May be difficult for students because:
-Outdated scheduling tools.  They use email to send you your schedule and any schedule changes need to be relayed in person.  This is because they refuse to use another company for help, i.e. no HotSchedules or anything streamlined like that
-Scheduling can arrive late but they insist on a 2 week notice for requests off
-Schedule never means anything, if your shift shows 5-9 the only thing that is certain is you start at 5.

headline: Good benefits, bad management
pros: Free meal every worked shift, family picnic, company store discount, matched 401k after a year, sports events, high wage for fat food
cons: Bad management, worked like a slave if you're a top performer, little room for growth if the store is overstaffed or trains poorly, customers are allowed to walk all over you

headline: Excellent place to work in high school or beginning of college.
pros:
Flexible hours
Great pay
Fun work environment 
Good experience
Teaches work ethic
A lot of young people
Helpful management
Free food!

Stressful at times
You begin to smell like fast food all the time
Having bad management can make a shift more stressful than necessary

headline: I truly loved it!
pros: Excellent pay, good enough hours, high company standards, no "secrets" hiding, fresh everything, fun place to be! I always felt welcomed and honestly the company cares a LOT about their staff and Guests!
cons: The only thing was struggling to advance to a higher level (aka more money) - I felt it was nearly impossible sometimes.

headline: Great first job
pros: Very accommodating, especially for college students. My shift was roughly 2am-10am, so it was probably quite a different experience than most INO employees. They were incredibly understanding with my having classes after each shift. Management was great and the environment there was overall pretty positive.
cons: Some pressure to be overly social with other employees (hence why I preferred working through the middle of the night)

headline: Level 7
pros: Fun environment and pay is good if you're a high school kid or living at home.
cons: Robots. Jocks run the company and stores

headline: Favoritism
pros:
-good pay
-teaches you to work hard and work quickly
-customer service skills 
-free meal every shift 
-getting to interacting with customers and hopefully make their day is awesome! 
-some managers are really cool and neutral.
cons:
-FAVORITISM 
-I would really rather move up because of hard work and not kissing butt.
-higher levels are really rude to lower levels. 
-poor training process. On several occasions I've felt stupid for not knowing something I was never taught. -If you're not a manager favorite they will not let you learn train in new positions.
-if you're not a favorite, you're easily forgotten and tossed to the side.  
-no one takes the time to train you even when you ask and even when it's not busy.
-sometimes the stress is overwhelming. There are really bad days when a lot will go wrong and frustrate you. Impatient managers do not help. 
-when you do something wrong sometimes it's humiliating when it really shouldn't be. 
-the managers are not supportive/encouraging and get mad at the weirdest/stupidest things. I was once taken out of a position because I didn't have my button in the right place on my shirt. 
-managers can be really mean. I was once actually called a hot mess because I made a mistake, became frustrated and cried. I found this completely inappropriate. 
-little to no recognition for hard work when you're not a favorite. 
I'm sure there's more I'm forgetting. 

Honestly it really all just depends on you and the store you work for. Sometimes it works out and sometimes it doesn't. I know some people ABSOLUTELY LOVE IT. I had a pretty bad experience. I'd recommend trying it out because of the awesome benefits and the skills you acquire.

headline: Amazing place to learn valuable lessons

headline: All Star
pros: (Mangers & some associates) Full medical benefits, paid vacation, 401K plan, paid meals, life insurance, high pay raises and an overall friendly and ethic driven workforce. The ability to move forward in this company is amazing. I'm not at liberty to disclose how much these people make or their managers, but I can tell you it's more than a lawyer in most cases. Getting to work with other great associates and in a awesome family environment. Very communicative and flexible place to work. I learned a ton of values and social responsibility working for this company. All of my management skills stemmed from this job.
cons: In my position it was the long, extensive hours. 65 hours a week. Other than that, I have NO complaints about this great company.

headline: Not what u expect
pros: Good pay and opportunities for growth.
cons: Unprofessional, not for college students, locks u in because pay is good.

headline: Great Job
pros: Flexible, room for improvement, good pay.
cons: Physically tiring, late hours, fast paced

headline: Associate
pros: It is a place that has a great environment to work in. Everyone is compassionate, and they teach you everything you need to know.
cons: I truly did not experience anything bad about this job. Just be ready to work hard, and be able to show up on time.

headline: Great Entry Level Jobs
pros: The company treats their employees really well.
cons: Smell like burgers at the end of your shift.

headline: IN N OUT
pros: free food, sick pay, and vacation hours. they are really great
cons: nothing. i love in n out  everybody is great, nice, friendly, i love everything

headline: Good Job for Teenagers and College Students
pros: Interacting with customers is fun, and the pay isn't bad.
cons: Never get off on time, sometimes they will let you go very early or keep you very late. Breaks are incredibly short. Also taking tips is against company policy.

headline: Great first Job!
author_position: In N Out Associate Lvl IV
pros: Everyone is very hard-working & the pay reflects the expectations. Learned great ethics here. Flexible work schedule for students!
cons: Sometimes, the work is exhausting when the store is understaffed. Need better procedures for this situation.

headline: Being an Associate
pros:
In-N-Out Burger is great first job for HighSchool/College students/. They will have flexible scheduling that will work around your school time and college classes. Opportunities to get a pay raise and its simple process, just have to be patient and work hard. Hours are long but the environment and atmosphere is great. 
-Reasonable people and they do not treat as workers, they care for your personal life and ask if there are any problems and are willing to reach out to you.
cons:
Closing at 1:30AM which means will not clock out until 2:30AM or later
Somebody calling off, expected to stay longer.
Smelling like spread/oil and your shoes will leave an odor in your car unless taken drastic measure

headline: Level 5
pros:
Community feel
Nice pay for burger joint
Can move up to manager if you work hard enough
Everyone starts at the same place
cons:
Extremely fast paced depending on store
Managers can be hard to work with

headline: In n out Burger
pros: Great company to work for! Great pay, free food every time you work. Coworkers and management are friendly and expect to be treated with kindness. The company truly cares about your well being and how you feel working at in n out, and does their absolute best to make you feel comfortable at work
cons: You'll rarely get off on time, long hours, expect to be called in all the time. Also very stressful, with constant long lines and very little time to get stuff done.

headline: Great Work Place
pros: Great pay and great benefits, and they can work with what ever is going on in your life to make a schedule that will work for you
cons: Always busy and you're constantly moving back and forth,  you will alwyas be tired.

headline: amazing place to work
pros: good paying, extremely flexible scheduling, great environment, good learning experience, free burger, awesome company
cons: shift times (late night), working on the holidays

headline: Associate
pros: great place to work, the environment/company are fantastic
cons: Have no cons to share.

headline: Best company!
pros: Great people, free meals, store parties. flexible schedule.
cons: mind numbing. smell like a cow when i come home

headline: LEVEL V
pros: teaches to be hardworking and to manage stress. really teaches you how to be aware of your surroundings and that sense of urgency
cons: you smell like burgers after every shift. its a very stressful job at times when you are understaffed with a line out the door

headline: In n out cashier
pros: Good company , diverse customers, great store owner
cons: Some co workers are very unfriendly , higher levels think they have the right to treat Lower levels like trash

headline: Level 4 Associate
pros:
Amazing corporation because of no franchises.
Great Pay.
cons:
Must be very available to get hours.
Strict sick policy.

headline: Manager
pros: They pay well, they care about their associates, lots of room for growth with in the company and the constantly challenge you to be better while promoting you to have high standards for your self and your team.
cons: It's a fast pace environment that isn't for the week in spit or mind. It is retail so your schedule off time is a guideline, if the business is there you're not getting off at you scheduled time. very strict grooming guidelines and dress code. Fast pace high volume place to work with very high repetitive motions while working positions.

headline: Level 4
pros: Great family and team oriented environment
cons: There is nothing I can say

headline: Associate
pros: You get a great starting wage
cons: You have to work a lot to move up

headline: Manager Assistant
pros: Ever since I started working for In N Out Burger my personal experience has been great, When I first started working with them as a entry level associate, I moved my way up to become a shift person in other words a manager, training attitude is always been amazing, personal training and individual engage with the associates is my passion.
cons: I been with the In N Out family for 14 years now, and the reason for me to seek or try to get another job is to explore more of a different world different environment  where I can develop more of all the skill and learning experience I have achieve with my In N Out family

headline: Level 5 associate
pros: Very flexible with your schedule and always willing to help you out if needed. Everyone is very positive and friendly.
cons: more often than not you get asked to stay a little bit longer than you're scheduled, but they make up for it by being flexible with you, so it balances out

headline: In-n-out associate
pros: Non-minimum wage job compare to other fast food chain. Great benefits and team members
cons: Working with 50 associates can be difficult specially starting with low level.

headline: Incredible Part time Job for people in school!
pros:
Pays higher than retail and other fast food places.
Free burger every break.
Very flexible schedules. During the school year I would only work on the weekends while in the summer 36 hour work weeks were common.
Raises about every 8 months if you try hard.
cons: In N Out is always going to be busy. From the morning the doors open to the night in which they close, there will always be a constant stream of customers. Because there will always be customers, everyone will be constantly stressed out. Get ready for short tempers.

headline: It was a good job
pros: It pays pretty well for a job
cons: Long hours and not very flexible

headline: Great place to work
pros: High pay, busy most of the time, and room for growth
cons: Tough/tiring work and tough to get days off sometimes

headline: Associate
pros: Flexible Schedules, great pay, fast-paced environment.
cons: Turn-over is very high. There will be rushes of new hires and it makes it difficult to work a shift with a bunch of new people who need training and not enough people to train the new workers.

headline: AMAZING Company
pros: This is an amazing company. They really know how to take care of their employees and make sure to treat everyone like family. The owner of the company really makes sure the employees are well cared for and trained.
cons: Be prepared to be on your feet all the time!

headline: Sales Associate
pros:
Good pay
Fun events to attend (parties, trips, sport games etc)
Free meal every shift
Good benefits
cons:
Too fast pace
Always on your feet
A lot of rude customers
Stressful/anxious environment

headline: Associate - Level 3
pros: Free food every shift, fun enviroment, and it was 12.50 starting pay in Pleasant Hill. Each "Level" has raises and tasks associated with achieving them. At Level 2 the pay was 12.75 and at 3 it 13.00. Awesome time.
cons: Hard work, and always expected to be working. Can be dull and repetitive after a few months.

headline: Working as a college student
pros: Great starting pay. Once you get past dinning room, ask for opportunities to work your way up. Great raises that way. Great training. Free Lunch, and dinner if you work 8 hour shift. Great job for college student.  Christmas and thanks giving off. and for other things you want,  if you asked in enough time ahead, likely to get time off. Sometimes working overtime.
cons: Standing for  6 hours a day every day., , working black Friday,  I worked in the outlets,  Grumpy customers sometimes, Only 10 minutes to eat your burger.

headline: In N Out
pros: They have great benefits  for full time employees, flexible, great pay.
cons: You can't be full time until you're at a certain level and sometimes it takes a while to move up.

headline: Great place
pros: Good pay. Good customer service
cons: No beards allowed on shift

headline: Great company!
pros: Open door policy, everyone is a family, learn important skills that are needed later on in the work place.
cons: Sometimes the scheduling is not accurate of how long you actually work. Hard to juggle while being a student.

headline: Great Place to Work
pros: Greater culture and career advancement
cons: The hours can be taxing and high amount of polices

headline: Good
pros: Flexible good pay good hours very good company
cons: Always busy hardly any weekends off closes late

headline: Fantastic first job
pros: Great management and coworkers, made the job a ton of fun. Free meals when you work, great opportunity for promotion, and fast-paced environment. Management was absolutely fantastic when working around my school schedule, always got the time I needed off. Great starting pay, and lots of opportunities for raises. Strong company values, and excellent training.
cons: Customers were sometimes rude, but that's pretty much unavoidable, just have to keep a level head and not let it get to you. Breaks were a little short, only 10 minutes/6 hr shift. During rush hours it can get a little overwhelming, but you get used to it! Not too many cons at all!

headline: Best company to work for
pros: This company really pushes you to grow to be a great person in your community and to grow as an employee. They help you gain skills and develop a positive work ethic you will use for the rest of your life. I was part time and worked 30-36 hours a weeks and the pay was very fair for the work they wanted in return. You start at 11 and after some time elapses, 3 months, 6 months, 1 year ect; you are given raises if you learn a new position. They praise you and coach you through development unique to you and you are given opportunities to go above and beyond. This is a very rewarding company to work for and it will feel like your second family in no time. I strongly suggest this company if your want to build onto your personal skill set but i do not recommend staying for more than 1 and a half years. The plus side of them really valuing you as an employee is that you will realize your potential and want to do better for yourself. I suggest striving to be your best because it will be recognized and appreciated but if you don't you will feel the retaliation from you fellow employees and management. Personally my store did an outstanding job with communication and staying on top of things and my store manager is was probably the best you can possibly have. Most of the managers are very understanding, and bring a sense of family to work and its very motivating.
cons: It can be rigorous and mentally draining since you are doing the same thing over and over an over again, every thirty seconds, for six hours, six days a week. After two years I got really tired of this and I felt as if the content push for perfection was too much. Not to mention you are pushed to connect with customers and be service oriented but its very hard to feel a human connection with people who enjoy the food if you feel like a robot instead.

headline: INO
pros: In-N-Out is a great company to work for. Invests heavily in the employees upon entry and does a fantastic job of fostering a unified culture
cons: High stress, fast paced job may be a con to some.

headline: Great first job.
pros: Great crew to work with, and a lot of opportunity to move up and make more $$$. Good starting wage, as well.
cons: Inconsistent hours. You may also stay way later than your schedule says due to demand.

headline: it was fun
pros: working there was so cool for awhile and everyone is really nice you meet alot of friends and once you move up your hours improve i enjoyed learning so much about good customer service.
cons: gets exhausting. youre not cool unless you know what you are doing in the kitchen and if youre new good luck everyone will be rude and dont expect to make friends or get good hours right away. everyone is pretty stuck up once they see youre learning the material though youre cool. i have issues with the strict policy which defeminishes woman and cant have nail polish. the uniform sucks and you have to stand outside and take orders which isnt fun. i had issues with one manager shes why i left i went to work everyday and sometimes i would leave crying. stressful. one word.

headline: Level 3
pros: Chance for advancement easily,  great pay, outstanding people to work with, fun, fast pace,  hands on training, paid holidays off, free meal on shift, family oriented employees
cons: Only because I HAVE to put something,  smelling like burgers when going home.

headline: Associate
pros: Great atmosphere, always keep you busy, fun, and company takes good care of us
cons: Gtes super crazy sometimes and a lot of time on your feet

headline: Great for One, not for All
pros: Most often times the environment is fast-paced and makes work go by faster and almost makes you feel like you're not at work at times.
cons: You have to be able to handle critique well because you will receive it from everyone and all the time because lots of workers are proud of the standards that In N Out has. This isn't necessarily a con if you handle criticism well though.

headline: Associate
pros: Good pay for fast food, free meals, flexibility in hours, ability to move up and try different positions and a great intro position for a student in high school or college
cons: Hours can be bad depending on if you close or not, very busy at peak hours and a lot of physical involved. You can end up being understaffed at times

headline: In N
pros: Fantastic health insurance, competitive pay
cons: People in store management positions are not qualified

headline: Part-time Associate
pros: The pay would have to be the only thing that made me stay an associate. Meeting a lot of people that were coworkers and customers. They hold many events and competitions throughout the year that let you mingle with associates from other stores. There are about 7 levels the last is management, moving up positions should be easy if you are willing to work hard and always ask managers what is required to move up in each level.
